content:
The Act may be cited as the "Safety, Accountability, and Funding Efficiency for Transportation Act of 2007". It includes findings related to transportation. The "Safety, Accountability, and Funding Efficiency for Transportation Act of 2007" emphasizes the importance of conducting cost-benefit analysis before procuring transportation services to ensure quality and cost-effectiveness. This analysis helps determine whether to use private contractors or government employees for such services. The Act defines "architectural, engineering, and related services" as various services related to construction projects and "private contract" as an agreement between a government agency and a private contractor. The curr_chunk discusses the definitions of "government agency," "Secretary," and "surface transportation project" in the context of agreements between government agencies and private contractors for surface transportation projects. The curr_chunk defines a project related to surface transportation as determined by the Secretary. SEC. 4. COST-BENEFIT ANALYSIS. For fiscal year 2009 and beyond, Federal funds for surface transportation projects can be used by government agencies for private contracts over $100,000 for architectural, engineering, and related services, if a cost-benefit analysis is conducted. The analysis must include a description of the services to be performed under the contract. The private contract must include a description of services, an estimate of procurement costs, and a comparison of costs between private and government agency performance. The private contract must include a description of services, an estimate of procurement costs, a comparison of costs between private and government agency performance, office facilities, equipment, and materials costs, determination of quicker procurement, government provision of equipment, and material cost estimate. (6) Estimate of unemployment compensation and benefits for displaced government agency employees.
(7) Estimate of cost for government agency to resume service under private contract. SEC. 5. DISCLOSURE OF RESULTS OF COST-BENEFIT ANALYSIS. Government agencies must disclose cost-benefit analysis results for private contracts at least 30 days before entering into the contract. Results must be submitted for review, provided to registered individuals or entities, and made available for public inspection, including online publication. SEC. 6. COMMENTS. During a 15-day period after a government agency publishes the results of a cost-benefit analysis for a private contract, employees and interested parties can submit written comments challenging the accuracy of the results. Additionally, agency employees can submit competitive bids to provide the services outlined in the contract. SEC. 7. USE OF QUALIFICATION-BASED SELECTION CRITERIA. In procuring architectural, engineering, and related services from private sources using Federal funds for surface transportation projects, government agencies must follow specific procedures outlined in federal or state qualifications-based requirements. SEC. 8. SPECIALTY, EMERGENCY, TEMPORARY WORK. The Secretary may waive the application of this Act for private contracts at the request of a government agency if the work is of an emergency, specialty, or intermittent nature and cannot be performed by government employees.
